pullRequest.body:
This PR defines (relative) CW-complexes in the original way Whitehead defined them: As a collection of cells that is closure finite and has weak topology. It additionally proves basic properties about them.

See [this discussion on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/two.20definitions.20of.20CW-complexes) about the two possible definitions.

Co-authered-by: Floris van Doorn <fpvdoorn@gmail.com>

---

I plan to add more about CW-complexes. My current formalization can be found [in this repository](https://github.com/scholzhannah/CWComplexes).

The modern definition (that is already in mathlib) can be found [here](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/CWComplex.html).

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body: messageFile.md

Two things I am unsure about (and need help with): 
- How should the two namespaces actually be done in practice. I don't thing the current export solution is very nice. Is the maybe some export tag?
- What should the name of these definitions actually be? Currently the naming clashes with the other definition.

This is great, I'm really happy to see this coming to Mathlib.

How much have you exercised the definition? E.g. how painful are products?

> This is great, I'm really happy to see this coming to Mathlib.
> 
> How much have you exercised the definition? E.g. how painful are products?

I think overall the definition feels good to work with. Always considering the relative case often makes the proofs a little bit more complicated than in the books. But I guess this just comes with generalization. And I am not knowledgeable enough to know whether specific statements are generally used in the relative or only in the absolute version.

Products are painful but I don't think they are too much more painful then they already are on paper. Mathematically I could basically just follow the proof in Hatcher.
messageFile.md

I've started to take a look, by reading from the beginning. I have some mainly stylistical comments (which should be independent of the open design questions).

Your first question: `export` is clever; I'd have to read up on if this does what you want. (Generally, one common solution in such situations is to have "morally the same" API twice.) 

About the second question, and the location of this file. There's indeed a name collision. The current scheme "RelCWComplex" versus "RelativeCWComplex" doesn't seem ideal yet... one could
- rename the abstract definitions "AbstractCWComplex" and "AbstractRelCWComplex", and name yours "ClassicalCWComplex" and "ClassicalRelCWComplex", or
- do some combination of these two, giving one name "preference" (i.e. "CWComplex" means the abstract one, "ClassicalCWComplex" is yours). I'm not convinced by this, though.

In any case, it would be helpful to have these definitions live next to each other. Perhaps move the existing file to `CWComplex/Basic.lean` and this file to `CWComplex/Classical.lean`? or `Abstract.lean` and `Classical.lean`? Perhaps this should be done once the naming is clearer...

These are not complete answers, but perhaps they're already helpful. Perhaps we can discuss more on Wednesday.

I've started to take a look, by reading from the beginning. I have some mainly stylistical comments (which should be independent of the open design questions).

Your first question: `export` is clever; I'd have to read up on if this does what you want. (Generally, one common solution in such situations is to have "morally the same" API twice.) 

About the second question, and the location of this file. There's indeed a name collision. The current scheme "RelCWComplex" versus "RelativeCWComplex" doesn't seem ideal yet... one could
- rename the abstract definitions "AbstractCWComplex" and "AbstractRelCWComplex", and name yours "ClassicalCWComplex" and "ClassicalRelCWComplex", or
- do some combination of these two, giving one name "preference" (i.e. "CWComplex" means the abstract one, "ClassicalCWComplex" is yours). I'm not convinced by this, though.

In any case, it would be helpful to have these definitions live next to each other. Perhaps move the existing file to `CWComplex/Basic.lean` and this file to `CWComplex/Classical.lean`? or `Abstract.lean` and `Classical.lean`? Perhaps this should be done once the naming is clearer...

These are not complete answers, but perhaps they're already helpful. Perhaps we can discuss more on Wednesday.

```suggestion
# CW complexes
(Please do the same throughout the file; I haven't labelled every instance.)

```suggestion
This file defines (relative) CW-complexes and proves basic properties about them.
I'd say "CW structures", and you have a typo "realtive"
Also: what is `D`? I'm reading the file from the top... if you mention it below, it's not clear at this point yet.
I'm surprised by the abbreviation `ClasCWComplex`: does this stand for "classical"? For the class of all CW complexes? (Then I'd expect at least `ClassCWComplex`.)
Yes, I did this spontaneously to get CI to stop complaining about the name being the same as for the other definition. It should definitely be different. I meant it to stand for classical.

minor comment: in English, you're supposed to continue in lower-case after a colon. (With very few exceptions.)
(This is different in e.g. German. Yes, this can be confusing.)
"boundary of a cell"? (I haven't heard of "edge" before. But then I use topology, but am not an algebraic topologist - so may be wrong.)
`RelCWComplex`, right?

How about rewriting the first two bullet points, a bit like the following? (Is what I am saying correct? I didn't read the implementation yet.)

We use the historical definition of CW complexes, due to Whitehead: a CW complex is a collection of cells with attaching maps --- all cells are subspaces of one ambient topological space. This way, we avoid having to work with a log of different topological spaces. On the other hand, it requires the subspaces to be closed.
If that is not the case, you need to consider that subspace as a subspace of itself.
I would just remove "A lot of lemmas will require `[T2Space X]`." I'm not sure what information this adds. What do you think?

What do you think about this phrasing?
"It is a bijection when restricted to `closedBall 0 1`, where we consider `(Fin n → ℝ)` endowed with the maximum metric."
Small detail: please use ` -/` (i.e., a space before the `-/` --- here and elsewhere.
Intuitively, I would call this `continuousOn`
and this `continuousOn_symm`
"use `RelCWComplex.pairwiseDisjoint` or `RelCWComplex.disjoint_openCell_of_ne` instead`"?
mentions `D`

Could you explain in more detail why you need this distinction between levelaux and level? 

Could we give it a more intuitive name? e.g. `below` or `cellsLT` or `skeletonLT`, etc?
Could we call this `skeleton`? It's the standard term here.

```suggestion
  This way, we avoid having to work with a lot of different topological spaces.
```
unless I'm missing a saying? 🪵

```suggestion
* For statements, the auxiliary construction `skeletonLT` is preferred over `skeleton` as it makes
```

Not sure I understand this docstring. The first sentence makes it sound like being a CW complex is a proposition, even though it's data. Maybe something like
```suggestion
/-- A CW complex of a topological space `X` relative to another subspace `D` is the data of its
*`n`-cells* `cell n i` for each `n : ℕ`  along with *attaching maps* ...

Note that this definition requires `C` and `D` to be closed subspaces.
If your `C` is not closed in `X` , choose `X` to be `C`. -/
```
(btw we don't indent docstrings by default)

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
    (cell : ℕ → Type u) (map : (n : ℕ)  → (i : cell n) → PartialEquiv (Fin n → ℝ) X)
```

```suggestion
requires `C` to be a closed subspace. If `C` is not closed choose `X` to be `C`. -/
```
or simply
```suggestion
  requires `C` to be closed. If `C` is not closed choose `X` to be `C`. -/
```

What is the issue with calling this
```suggestion
abbrev CWComplex {X : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] (C : Set X) := RelCWComplex C ∅
```
?

This clashes with https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/CWComplex.html#CWComplex
My suggestion (in person was): put everything in here in the `Topology` namespace, and everything already existing in the `CategoryTheory` namespace (it's also topology, but I think it's clear enough).
Yep, I like your suggestion.
Do you actually need this `export`? Dot notation resolves across `abbrev`
This isn't really for dot notation. I just want shorter names when in the CWComplex namespace.
Do we really want this to be a class? I don't have a clear answer but I would have expected it to be "no" because a given topological space can be decomposed as a CW complex in many ways

I have two reasons as to why I like this being a class. Firstly, the majority of the code I have written is about different constructions (e.g. subcomplexes and products) and properties (mainly finiteness) about them. It is really convenient to talk about finiteness of a subcomplex without having to specify every time why that statement even makes sense, especially if you start taking unions of subcomplexes and things like that. I am not sure at all about my second point but I think a lot of the time you actually care more that a space is a CW-complex (with some property maybe) than about the actual CW-structure, i.e. I think a lot of times being a CW-complex is treated as a property rather than data.
Can you incorporate this explanation in some form in the `## Implementation notes` section of the module doc?
Sure!

pullRequest.title: feat: definition and basic lemmas about CW-complexes
